Citation.Paragraph:
In this revision of the Malagasy
Monomorium Monomorium ant fauna, thirty-six species are recognized, nineteen of them here described as new. The new species are
Monomorium adiastolon Monomorium adiastolon , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium aureorugosum M. aureorugosum , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium bifidoclypeatum M. bifidoclypeatum , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium chnodes M. chnodes , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium clarinodis M. clarinodis , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium denticulus M. denticulus , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium ferodens M. ferodens , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium fisheri M. fisheri , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium flavimembra M. flavimembra , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium gongromos M. gongromos , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium infuscum M. infuscum , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium lepidum M. lepidum , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium micrommaton M. micrommaton , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium nigricans M. nigricans , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium notorthotenes M. notorthotenes , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium platynodis M. platynodis , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium robertsoni M. robertsoni , sp. nov. ,
Monomorium versicolor M. versicolor , sp. nov. , and
Monomorium xuthosoma M. xuthosoma , sp. nov. Five species (four described from African material) pass into synonymy:
Monomorium leopoldinum M. leopoldinum Forel 1905
Citation.Name: Forel

with
Monomorium madecassum M. madecassum Forel 1892

and

Citation.Name: Forel

to become a junior synonym of

Citation.Name: Forel

Citation.Paragraph:
The Malagasy species are distributed among seven species groups. Previously recognized in the literature are the destructor-, hanneli-, latinode-, monomorium- and salomonis- groups. The
Monomorium hildebrandti hildebrandti species group comprises six new species as well as those formerly assigned to the
Monomorium fossulatum fossulatum species group. (Prior to this revision,
Monomorium fossulatum fossulatum Emery 1895
Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
was relegated to synonymy under
Monomorium sechellense sechellense Emery 1894
Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
and
Monomorium hildebrandti hildebrandti Forel 1892
Citation.Name: Forel

Citation.Paragraph: 1 Current address: Research Fellow, Department of Environmental Biology, Curtin University of Technology, GPO Box U 1987
Citation.Name: U

Fernandez, in press) means that the autonomy of the small solenopsidine genera
Anillomyrma Anillomyrma ,
Megalomyrmex Megalomyrmex and, possibly,
Bondroitia Bondroitia is under threat. Genera linked with
Solenopsis Solenopsis and with
Allomerus Allomerus , which have a broader suite of distinctive anatomical features than the abovementioned (see Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Monomorium Monomorium is given in Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Six taxa assigned to
Monomorium Monomorium have been described from material collected from Madagascar.
Monomorium hildebrandti Monomorium hildebrandti ,
Monomorium imerinense Monomorium imerinense and
Monomorium madecassum Monomorium madecassum were described by Forel in the same publication as supposed races of
Monomorium minutum Monomorium minutum Mayr (Forel 1892
Citation.Name: Forel

Monomorium termitobium Monomorium termitobium as a species in its own right.

Citation.Paragraph:
A summary of what was known about the Monomorium fauna of Madagascar and associated islands before the commencement of this project is provided below. "from inspection" refers to placement of a taxon in a particular species group as a result of examination of material during this project. These taxa had not been assigned to a species group or category prior to this project, although an available group did exist. No group was available for
Monomorium shuckardi Monomorium shuckardi Forel , and I have not seen material belonging to
Monomorium elongatum Monomorium elongatum Smith . (Nb: With the exception of the
Monomorium hildebrandti M. hildebrandti species group, the groups mentioned are those recognized by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Monomorium salomonis Monomorium salomonis (L.) has also been listed as occurring in Madagascar (Fisher 1997
Citation.Name: Fisher

Citation.Paragraph: Fisher 2003
Citation.Name: Fisher

Monomorium Monomorium species were generated using the DELTA (DEscription Language for TAxonomy) computer program (Dallwitz, Paine, and Zurcher 2000
Citation.Name: Dallwitz, Paine, and Zurcher

Citation.Paragraph:
Seen in profile, mesoscutum ranges from broadly convex to convex anteriad and flattened or even faintly sinuate posteriad. Mesoscutal pilosity always present. Pronotum, mesoscutum and mesopleuron often smooth and shining, but may be striolate or punctate to a greater or smaller degree; mesopleuron always divided by transverse furrow into upper anepisternum and lower katepisternum. Length-width ratio of mesoscutum and scutellum from near 7:3 to about 3:2. Axillae mostly well separated but may be contiguous or even reduced to a strip of thin cuticle, each individual axilla being indistinct. Metapleural sculpture most commonly in form of longitudinal striolae or striae, propodeum often unsculptured except for costulae on declivitous face, but where present frequently more marked than in conspecific worker. Dorsal propodeal face characteristically sloped, often almost vertical. Propodeal processes, where present, in form of small denticles or flanges, at most. Wing veins tubular and sclerotised in
Monomorium notorthotenes M. notorthotenes ,
Monomorium hanneli M. hanneli , and in
Monomorium hildebrandti M. hildebrandti group, predominantly weak and depigmented in most
Monomorium monomorium M. monomorium group species, though wing veins are darkly pigmented without accompanying sclerotization in some species. Cross-vein m-cu present in all queens of
Monomorium hildebrandti M. hildebrandti group, in all
Monomorium notorthotenes M. notorthotenes queens and some
Monomorium hanneli M. hanneli queens, absent in other
Monomorium hanneli M. hanneli queens, rarely present in reproductives of
Monomorium destructor M. destructor group (per Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
and always absent in reproductives of
Monomorium monomorium M. monomorium and M.
Monomorium salomonis salomonis groups (information on the latter coming from Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
the Malagasy
Monomorium Monomorium fauna has strong African affinities, and shares a number of species with eastern and southern Africa. However, several shared taxa have their distribution primarily in the middle and western parts of Africa. By way of contrast, the Malagasy representatives of another myrmicine genus, Pyramica, have much more decidedly Asian affinities (Fisher 2003
Citation.Name: Fisher

Citation.Paragraph:
and with members of the
Monomorium scabriceps M. scabriceps group (Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
However, other morphological features suggest a relationship at a basal level with the
Monomorium destructor Monomorium destructor and
Monomorium salomonis Monomorium salomonis groups. These include the specialized small males (albeit, only known for
Monomorium notorthotenes Monomorium notorthotenes Heterick , sp. nov. ) also found in the
Monomorium destructor M. destructor group (Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Monomorium subcoecum Monomorium subcoecum (not found in Madagascar) was described by Emery from the Antilles, in the Caribbean (Emery 1894
Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
b). However, whereas these two entities appear to constitute only a minor fraction of the African
Monomorium Monomorium fauna (with the exception of the widespread
Monomorium cryptobium Monomorium cryptobium ), several of the species recognized in this work are abundant and widespread throughout Madagascar. As understood in this work, the
Monomorium hildebrandti M. hildebrandti species group includes those species placed by Bolton in the
Monomorium fossulatum M. fossulatum species group. The name
Monomorium hildebrandti hildebrandti is here preferred as the designation of this group because this was the earliest named species, and the name "
Monomorium fossulatum fossulatum " has been synonymized under
Monomorium sechellense sechellense (Bolton 1995
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Monomorium hanneli Monomorium hanneli bears a strong superficial resemblance to members of the
Monomorium hildebrandti M. hildebrandti group in which the clypeal carinae are well-developed and the clypeus is projected forward. The appearance of the mesosoma is also similar, if not identical, and the compound eye in workers of
Monomorium hanneli M. hanneli and workers of most
Monomorium hildebrandti M. hildebrandti group species is reduced. However, as Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
The
Monomorium destructor M. destructor and
Monomorium salomonis M. salomonis species groups are represented by few species, and these are mainly tramp ants. Within the
Monomorium destructor M. destructor group,
Monomorium destructor Monomorium destructor is adventive to the island, having been brought across by human commerce at some time in the past, but the widespread distribution of
Monomorium robustior Monomorium robustior suggests endemicity (thus also Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Within the
Monomorium salomonis M. salomonis group,
Monomorium pharaonis Monomorium pharaonis and
Monomorium subopacum Monomorium subopacum , members of different complexes but with similar tramp tendencies, have clearly been introduced. The presence of
Monomorium willowmorense Monomorium willowmorense , known from one worker collected from the north-east coast, is more puzzling. The monotypic
Monomorium latinode Monomorium latinode species group is represented by
Monomorium latinode M. latinode , which also has tramp tendencies, and is well-dispersed across the Indo-Australian region (Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Monomorium monomorium Monomorium monomorium species group members found in Madagascar are often abundant, but are not particularly diverse compared with the Afrotropical fauna, only 15 species being recognized here. It should be said, however, that the variability of several nominal species like
Monomorium termitobium M. termitobium is so great that molecular-based systematics is probably needed to give the taxonomy strong definition. Some of the taxa appear to belong to complexes identified by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Name: Forel

Remarks.-
Monomorium robustior Monomorium robustior has a wider known distribution than
Monomorium destructor M. destructor in Madagascar, mainly in more southerly regions (Antananarivo, Fianarantsoa, Mahajanga and Toliara Provinces). Specimens have been collected by a variety of means in dry tropical and spiny forest. In Africa, this species has been recorded from Kenya and Somalia (Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

even if

Two workers, originally on the same pin as the lectotype, have been repinned with photocopies of the original labels. NB. The original syntype series of 43 workers included a worker of another species, whose appearance agrees with the description of
Monomorium medinae Monomorium medinae Forel (type material not seen). This is a member of the
Monomorium salomonis M. salomonis group, endemic to the Canary Islands (Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Remarks.- Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Several of the synonyms are those of taxa originally described from males. The spurious genus "
Paraphacota Paraphacota " incorporated three such taxa, and what appears to me to be two distinct species. The male of
Monomorium surcoufi Monomorium surcoufi and that of
Monomorium cabrerai M. cabrerai are obviously identical, and easily recognized by their long, bicolored legs and completely hyaline wings. On the other hand, the male of
Monomorium cabrerai obscuripes Monomorium cabrerai obscuripes has relatively shorter, uniformly dark legs and brown wing veins. I have not seen nest material of
Monomorium subopacum Monomorium subopacum that has included males, but Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
included the two
Monomorium cabrerai cabrerai taxa under
Monomorium medinae Monomorium medinae , but omitted
Monomorium surcoufi Monomorium surcoufi . This seems to me an odd judgement, and, indeed, Bolton (1995
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Monomorium subopacum Monomorium subopacum , like
Monomorium pharaonis Monomorium pharaonis , is something of a tramp, and its occurrence in Madagascar and other regions well away from its natural area of occurrence is certainly due to human activities (Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
NHMB - Reg. No. 207). The lectotype fixes the name for populations of this taxon, which appears to be essentially the same as
Monomorium faurei M. faurei , though said by Santschi to have a more deeply incised metanotal groove. The lectotype is headless. (NB. This specimen is described as a "holotype" by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Based on comparative type material I have seen,
Monomorium exiguum Monomorium exiguum is part of a complex that includes, at least, the exclusively African
Monomorium mictile Monomorium mictile Forel ,
Monomorium rosae Monomorium rosae Santschi and
Monomorium taedium Monomorium taedium Bolton . An 11-segmented antenna, an elongate and flattened head capsule, weakly developed clypeal carinae, a dorsally rather flattened rather than evenly convex propodeum and the low, strongly conical form of the petiole are common to all of these taxa.
Monomorium rosae Monomorium rosae is placed in a different complex by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
The distinction between the above four species, if indeed it truly exists, is minimal. In appearance the workers form a continuum, with the bright yellow
Monomorium mictile M. mictile being the smallest species and the very dark
Monomorium rosae M. rosae the largest. To give just one instance, the relevant measurements supplied by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Monomorium mictile Monomorium mictile is separated from
Monomorium exiguum M. exiguum by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:

Citation.Paragraph:
Material examined.-
Monomorium madecassum M. madecassum : Lectotype: [[worker]], Madagascar, Imerina, coll. [P.] Camboue (MHNG). This specimen is designated the lectotype to fix the name for the species. Malagasy workers are generally smaller and less hairy than workers collected in Africa. Paralectotypes: (i) [[worker]], Madagascar, Imerina, coll. [F.] Sikora (MHNG). (ii) [[queen]], Madagascar, Imerina, coll. [P.] Sikora (MHNG).
Monomorium leopoldinum M. leopoldinum : Lectotype: [[worker]], Democratic republic of Congo: St. Gabriel, Stanleyville, P. Kohl (MHNG). A lectotype is designated to fix the name
Monomorium leopoldinum leopoldinum " under which were placed certain African populations of what is here regarded as
Monomorium madecassum M. madecassum . Paralectotypes: Two workers, same data as lectotype (MHNG). Repinned, with photocopies of the original labels.
Monomorium explorator M. explorator : Holotype: [[worker]], Gabon, Samkita, F Faure (NHMB - Reg. no. 206). Santschi mentions only the one specimen was used for his description.
Monomorium aequum M. aequum : Holotype: [[worker]], Democratic Republic of Congo, Stanleyville, Reichensperger (NHMB - Reg. No. 216). This worker was designated a "holotype" by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Remarks.- Workers of
Monomorium madecassum Monomorium madecassum are immediately recognizable by virtue of their large propodeal spiracle, clypeal denticles, and relatively large eyes. The petiolar node and postpetiole also tend to be high and narrow in most specimens. The taxon
Monomorium leopoldinum Monomorium leopoldinum , described from African material, is morphologically indistinguishable from
Monomorium madecassum M. madecassum and is here made a junior synonym of the earlier name.
Monomorium aequum Monomorium aequum was collected in the same locality (Stanleyville, Democratic Republic of Congo) as
Monomorium leopoldinum M. leopoldinum , and apart from smaller eyes and a broad head the lectotype is virtually indistinguishable from that of
Monomorium leopoldinum M. leopoldinum .
Monomorium explorator Monomorium explorator Santschi , from Gabon, has a smooth mesopleuron without any hint of sculpture. Otherwise, however, it conforms closely to
Monomorium madecassum M. madecassum . African populations of
Monomorium madecassum M. madecassum are on average larger than Malagasy populations of this species. Workers also tend to be more hirsute, with more than two pairs of erect propodeal setae, according to Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: ton

Citation.Paragraph:
Remarks.- This smallish species, the only Malagasy
Monomorium Monomorium apart from
Monomorium exiguum Monomorium exiguum that has an 11-segmented antenna, appears to be confined to Toliara Province, where it is not uncommon in spiny forest. Several workers and males have also been collected in gallery and tropical dry forests. The profile of the worker mesosoma of
Monomorium nigricans Monomorium nigricans is not unlike that of the African
Monomorium bequaerti Monomorium bequaerti Forel (Fig. 92 in Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Monomorium termitobium Monomorium termitobium Forel , 1892
Citation.Name: Forel

Citation.Name: Forel

Citation.Name: M

Citation.Paragraph: Monomorium imerinense Monomorium imerinense Dalla Torre , 1893
Citation.Name: Dalla Torre

Citation.Paragraph: Monomorium binatu Monomorium binatu Bolton , 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Six workers, with same data as the holotype (MCZ). (Relevant measurements of the holotype and paratypes are provided in Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
The impression I am left with, after many hours of examination of these specimens, is that a single founder species of African origin has given rise to branches in which speciation at this point of time is almost, but not quite complete. Although some worker and queen morphotypes include distinctive individuals or populations of individuals, this does not hold true for the members of all populations of that morphotype, and the distinctions therefore cannot be expressed in a taxonomic key. Differences between the known males, however, are greater and may be significant. With all of the preceding aspects in mind, I am provisionally synonymizing
Monomorium binatu Monomorium binatu Bolton ,
Monomorium exchao Monomorium exchao Santschi and
Monomorium imerinense Monomorium imerinense Forel under the earliest name,
Monomorium termitobium Monomorium termitobium Forel . The affinities of
Monomorium termitobium M. termitobium in its various incarnations seem to lie with the
Monomorium rhopalocerum M. rhopalocerum group, but I am ascribing to the latter a greater degree of morphological variability than expressed by Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Name: Forel

Citation.Paragraph:
Remarks.- At the time of writing, type material for
Monomorium modestum Monomorium modestum is missing (per Dr. D. Burckhardt, NHMB, pers. commun.), and the syntype of
Monomorium modestum transwaalense Monomorium modestum transwaalense (i.e., previously
Monomorium modestum boerorum M. modestum boerorum ) available to me for examination is headless, hence the identification of the Malagasy material as
Monomorium modestum Monomorium modestum is provisional. Bolton (1987
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
64. Syn. under
Monomorium sechellense Monomorium sechellense Bolton , 1995
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Remarks.- Its sculptured mesopleuron immediately enables the
Monomorium sechellense Monomorium sechellense worker to be distinguished from the worker of
Monomorium cryptobium M. cryptobium and
Monomorium modestum M. modestum . Queens are larger, darker and more heavily sculptured than those of
Monomorium cryptobium M. cryptobium . As has been the case with
Monomorium modestum M. modestum , sifted litter has been the most effective collection method for individual workers of
Monomorium sechellense M. sechellense , though one small nest series was taken from a rotten log. The species is found in dry tropical forest and gallery forest habitats in Antsiranana, Mahajanga and Toliara Provinces. Outside of Madagascar, this species has a wide distribution in the Indo-Pacific region (e.g., Bolton 1987
Citation.Name: e.g., Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Figures 1-13. Figures 1-3: Measurements used in this study (
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum worker) (1) HML, length of head +mesosoma(alitrunk)+petiole+postpetiole; (2) HL, head length; HW, head width; SL, scape length; (3) PW, promesonotal width. (Pilosity is omitted in Figs. 1-12.) Scale bars: Fig 1 = 0.5 mm; Figs 2-3, = 0.1mm. Figure 4. Profile of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum worker. A1-4, abdominal segments; ai, antennal insertion; ap, anteroventral process; E, eye; HC, head capsule; Mes, mesopleuron(Nb. In some species, the mesopleuron may be divided by a furrow into an upper anepisternum and a lower katepisternum); Mp, metapleuron; mpg, metapleural gland bulla; mtg, metanotal groove; P, propodeum (= first abdominal segment); ped, peduncle of petiole; PM, promesonotum; pp, propleuron; pps, propodeal spiracle; Ppt, postpetiole; Pt, petiole; pts, petiolar spiracle. Scale bar = 0.5 mm. Figure 5. Full-face view of head of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum worker. acs, anteromedian clypeal sector; C, clypeus; ca, clypeal angle (may be produced as denticle or tooth); cc, median clypeal carina; f, funiculus of antenna; fl, frontal lobe; frons, frons of head capsule; ft, frontal triangle; ms, median seta; scape, scape of antenna. Scale bar = 0.1 mm. Figure 6. Dorsal view of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum queen thorax. Scale bar = 0.5 mm. Figure 7. Profile of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum queen. an, anepisternum; ax, axilla; k, katepisternum; Ms, mesoscutum; Mt, metanotum; Oc, ocelli; P, propodeum; pp, propleuron; Pr, pronotum; Sc, scutellum. Scale bar = 1 mm. Figure 8. Full-face view of head of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum queen. Scale bar = 0.2 mm. Figure 9. Full-face view of head of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum male. Scale bar = 0.2 mm. Figure 10. Profile of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum male. ae, aedeagus; An, anepisternum; ax, axilla; k, katepisternum; Ms, mesoscutum; P, propodeum; pm (l), left paramere; pm (r), right paramere; Pr, pronotum. Scale bar = 1 mm. Figure 11. Dorsal view of
Monomorium sakalavum M. sakalavum male thorax. ax, axilla; mes, mesosoma; not, notaulus (vestigial here); pl, parapsidal line; sc, scutellum. Scale bar = 1 mm. Figure 12. Wing of
Monomorium fisheri M. fisheri showing the maximum complement of wing veins found in
Monomorium Monomorium . Scale bar = 1 mm. Figure 13. Inclination of a seta on body surface (terms used are taken from Dubois 1986
Citation.Name: Dubois
